paragraphs.text:
%md
> Exploring data, training a model, and making predictions

## Welcome to Getting Started with InsightEdge

This sample application uses flight delay data to make binary predictions (yes/no) about which flights are likely to get delayed. It takes you through the following steps:

* Fetching data and loading it to the InsightEdge platform
* Exploring the data using Spark and SQL queries
* Enriching the data and processing it to get the relevant feature vector
* Building and training a Machine Learning (ML) model for predicting flight delays
* Testing the ML model with real data

To run the code and see the results in the notebook, click  the `Run` icon in each paragraph (located in the top right corner).

### Fetching and Exploring the Data

For this application, we'll load sample data from a CSV file to the data grid. We can then explore it a bit using SQL queries. 

### Processing the Data for the ML Model

We will use InsightEdge Spark queries to transform the flight data information to get what we need to train the ML model, so that it can make accurate flight delay predictions. The initial data includes (per flight) date, airport of origin, destination, airline, departure delay, etc. This data will then be enriched with basic weather data at the airport of origin at the time of departure.

### Selecting an ML Model

There are many ML models available. The model that we felt is best suited for this task is the `Random (Decision) Forest`. 
Flight delays are measured in minutes, positive number is the delay in minutes while negative number indicate a flight that was early.
We will use data such as the month, day and departure time as well as origin and destination airports as features we will feed into an ML model, in our case, Random Forest, to train it for best accuracy. 
We will also supplement the feature vector with weather related data such as rain, wind and temperature. 

##### We will use:
*2017 data for training our model
*2018 data for evaluating our model accuracy
*Then we will stream 2019 data and predict if the flight will get delayed.

msg.data:
Exploring data, training a model, and making predictions

Welcome to Getting Started with InsightEdge

This sample application uses flight delay data to make binary predictions (yes/no) about which flights are likely to get delayed. It takes you through the following steps:

  • Fetching data and loading it to the InsightEdge platform
  • Exploring the data using Spark and SQL queries
  • Enriching the data and processing it to get the relevant feature vector
  • Building and training a Machine Learning (ML) model for predicting flight delays
  • Testing the ML model with real data

To run the code and see the results in the notebook, click the Run icon in each paragraph (located in the top right corner).

Fetching and Exploring the Data

For this application, we’ll load sample data from a CSV file to the data grid. We can then explore it a bit using SQL queries.

Processing the Data for the ML Model

We will use InsightEdge Spark queries to transform the flight data information to get what we need to train the ML model, so that it can make accurate flight delay predictions. The initial data includes (per flight) date, airport of origin, destination, airline, departure delay, etc. This data will then be enriched with basic weather data at the airport of origin at the time of departure.

Selecting an ML Model

There are many ML models available. The model that we felt is best suited for this task is the Random (Decision) Forest.
Flight delays are measured in minutes, positive number is the delay in minutes while negative number indicate a flight that was early.
We will use data such as the month, day and departure time as well as origin and destination airports as features we will feed into an ML model, in our case, Random Forest, to train it for best accuracy.
We will also supplement the feature vector with weather related data such as rain, wind and temperature.

We will use:

*2017 data for training our model
*2018 data for evaluating our model accuracy
*Then we will stream 2019 data and predict if the flight will get delayed.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Fetching and Exploring the Data

The data is in CSV file format. (If the data is not available for some reason, you can download it from: <https://insightedge-gettingstarted.s3.amazonaws.com/flightdelays20172018.csv.zip>)
After the data is loaded, explore the data with the provided SQL statements to understand the schema and how it behaves.

paragraphs.title: Total number of flights vs. number of delayed flights (by airport of origin)
paragraphs.text:
%sql

select Origin, count(*) as TotalFlights, SUM(DepDel15) as DelayedFlightsCount from FlightDelays group by Origin order by  DelayedFlightsCount/TotalFlights desc limit 15

paragraphs.title: Airport popularity
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select origin, count(*) as vol from  FlightDelays group by origin order by vol desc

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Transforming and Enriching the Flight Data

This step applies InsightEdge capabilities to transform the data into the required format, and enrich it with weather data. the data is processed as follows:

* Configure an InsightEdge context
* Provide InsightEdge with Type information about the data that was loaded
* Load the data to the InsightEdge in-memory store (to speed up data access)

msg.data:
Transforming and Enriching the Flight Data

This step applies InsightEdge capabilities to transform the data into the required format, and enrich it with weather data. the data is processed as follows:

  • Configure an InsightEdge context
  • Provide InsightEdge with Type information about the data that was loaded
  • Load the data to the InsightEdge in-memory store (to speed up data access)

paragraphs.title: Initialize Spark with InsightEdge context
paragraphs.text:
%spark

import org.insightedge.spark.implicits.all._
import org.insightedge.spark.context.InsightEdgeConfig

//Change space name here if not working with default
val ieConfig = new InsightEdgeConfig("flights_space")

sc.initializeInsightEdgeContext(ieConfig)

msg.data:
import org.insightedge.spark.implicits.all._
import org.insightedge.spark.context.InsightEdgeConfig
ieConfig: org.insightedge.spark.context.InsightEdgeConfig = InsightEdgeConfig(flights_space,None,None)
res2: org.apache.spark.SparkContext = org.apache.spark.SparkContext@19f18fd4

paragraphs.title: Write the FlightDelay data to the in-memory store
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode
import model.v1._

print("Writing to in-memory store " + flightDelaysDataFrame.count + "entries")

val flightDelaysRDD = flightDelaysDataFrame.map{rec =>  val fdww = FlightDelaysWithWeather(null, ""+rec.getAs("Reporting_Airline") , ""+rec.getAs("Flight_Number") ,(""+rec.getAs("Year")).toInt,""+rec.getAs("Month"),""+rec(2),""+rec.getAs("DayOfWeek"),""+rec.getAs("CRSDepTime"),(""+rec.getAs("DepDel15")).toDouble,(""+rec.getAs("DepDelay")).toDouble,""+rec.getAs("Origin"),""+rec.getAs("Dest"), null, null, null, null, null, null, null, null)
                                                        fdww.generate_id()
                                                        fdww
                                                }
sc.grid.clear("FlightDelaysWithWeather")
flightDelaysRDD.rdd.saveToGrid()

msg.data:
Writing to in-memory store 525238entries2019-10-31 13:34:17,192 CONFIG [com.gigaspaces.logger] - Log file: /opt/gigaspaces/logs/2019-10-31~13.34-gigaspaces-service-10.4.1.142-284.log
import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode
import model.v1._
flightDelaysRDD: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[model.v1.FlightDelaysWithWeather] = [id: string, carrier: string ... 18 more fields]

paragraphs.title: Query the data directly from the in-memory data grid
paragraphs.text:
%insightedge_jdbc

select id, "year", "month", dayofMonth, dayOfWeek, crsDepTime, flight_number, origin, dest, depDelay from FlightDelaysWithWeather limit 5

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Access the in-memory store using InsightEdge's predicate pushdown for better performance
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val airports = List ("ORD","DFW","DEN","SFO")


val origin =  z.select("origin", Seq(("ORD","O'hare International (chicago)"),
                                                  ("DFW","Dallas International"),
                                                  ("DEN", "Denver"), 
                                                  ("SFO", "San Francissco")))
val filtered_df = spark.read.grid[FlightDelaysWithWeather].where("depDelay > 0 and origin = '" + origin  + "'")
filtered_df.describe("depDelay").show

filtered_df: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[org.apache.spark.sql.Row] = [id: string, carrier: string ... 18 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
%insightedge_jdbc

select flight_number,  (1 -sum( depDelay15)/count(depDelay15)) as on_time_ratio, max(depDelay) as max_delay from FlightDelaysWithWeather group by flight_number  having   count(depDelay15) > 100 order by on_time_ratio desc  limit 10
